description:
Abrostola tripartita, commonly known as the golden twin-spot, is a species of moth belonging to the family Noctuidae. This species is native to Europe and is found across the continent, including the United Kingdom, Scandinavia, and parts of Russia.

The moth has a wingspan of approximately 35-40 millimeters. Its forewings are typically greyish-brown in color, with distinctive golden-yellow patches near the base and apex of the wing. The hindwings are greyish-brown in color.

The larvae, or caterpillars, of Abrostola tripartita feed on various plant species, including nettle (Urtica spp.), dead-nettle (Lamium spp.), and hops (Humulus lupulus). The caterpillars are typically green or brown in color, with distinctive markings along their bodies.

The species is known to have two generations per year, with adults typically observed during the spring and summer months. Abrostola tripartita is considered a relatively common and widespread species within its native range.
